Sok S. grows various crops on her farmland, and she now plants rice and peanuts. Her husband helps her to grow crops and is pictured in the photo. The coming rainfall is good for planting her crops, so Sok S. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for additional planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for additional planting

loans.name: Carmen

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carmen has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Carmen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from ASKI. Carmen is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Carmen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. S. is a housewife while her husband is employed preparing firewood, earning an income of about USD 7.50 per day. S. has to spend USD 40 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water, and USD 38 on other necessary expenses every month.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily A. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 58 years old and widowed. She has seven children and some of them are already married. She supports her family through farming. She plants and harvests rice for sale. She used to farm with her husband. Now that her husband is deceased, her children help her maintain the rice farm. Emily is eager to improve her farm so she can also earn more.

Emily joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Bebeth

texts.en:
Bebeth is a devoted mother to her three children. She is married to her loving spouse and lives in the beautiful province of Teresa, Rizal. She and her husband are operating a sari-sari (variety) store. Despite many challenges in their life, they never give up the fight against poverty.

During her 4 years at ASHI, she has shown very good performance as a member, and she is trusted by ASHI for her solid record. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in repayment, business, and attendance in ASHI, Bebeth has also cared for the needs of her children at home and in school.

Bebeth plans to use her new loans to expanded her variety store. This loan will enable her to finally reach her dreams in life: to have a growing business, to build a concrete and spacious home to live in, to have a good life, and to have a happy family as well. She hopes the loans from ASHI, Kiva's field partner, will support the education of all her children. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the educational needs of her children. She is very grateful to ASHI and Kiva for the continuous love and support of her dreams.

Bebeth hopes her business will continue to flourish so she can provide long-term financial stability for her family. Therefore, she is now requesting another Kiva loan, this time for 40,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), to purchase more groceries for her store. This will allow her to grow her business further so that her three children can fulfill their dreams of completing a college degree and experience a life that’s full of contentment. 

Bebeth is very happy to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for offering financial support for her business dreams.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Chhourn

texts.en: Chhourn C., 45, is married and resides with her husband and four children in the Cambodian province of Kampong Cham, an area known for rubber plantations. C. is a housewife, while her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about 3.50 USD per day. C. has to spend 40 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity and water supplies, and 38 USD on other necessary expenses every month. C. is requesting a loan of 600 USD for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: For family use

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta L. is from Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 56 years old, widowed and has 3 adult-aged children. Benedicta owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Benedicta has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Benedicta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benedicta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Benedicta is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase sewing materials. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Benedicta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

She said she and her husband hope for bright futures for their children. 

Gemalyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Gemalyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. S. and her husband grow rice, produce rice wine, and raise pigs, earning an income of about $5 US each per day. S. has to spend $56 US on food, $5 US on electricity and water supplies, and $10 US on other necessary expenses every month. S. has to spend US $75 on food, US $3 on electricity and water supplies, and US $13 on other necessary expenses every month. O. sells vegetables, earning an income of about US $2 per day. Her husband is a recycler, earning an income of about US $2 per day. O. has to spend US $66 on food, US $2 on electricity and water supplies, and US $10 on other necessary expenses every month. O. is requesting a loan of US $400 to purchase a new motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. O. appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna M. is from Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 43 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Myrna owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2005, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Myrna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Rosie has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

Rosie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Rosie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Chea

N. produces traditional baskets to sell, earning an income of about US $3 per day. Her husband is a famer and a construction worker, earning an income of about US $3 per day. N. has to spend US $50 on food, US $5 on electricity and water supplies, and US $15 on other necessary expenses every month. N. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase a plot of farmland to produce more rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea T., 52, is married and lives with her husband and five children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. T. and her husband grow rice, earning an income of about US $2 each per day. T. has to spend US $38 on food, US $3 on electricity and water supplies, and US $10 on other necessary expenses every month. T. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. T.'s husband and her family appear in the photograph because T. was not available.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland to grow more rice

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem T., 51, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. T. sells vegetables, earning an income of about US $3 per day. Her husband produces traditional baskets to sell, earning an income of US $1 per day. T. has to spend US $50 on food, US $3 on electricity and water supplies, and US $30 on other necessary expenses every month. T. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase more supplies to produce traditional baskets. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more supplies to produce traditional baskets

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok S., 63, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for a Pre-Angkorean temple. S. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about 1 USD each per day. Three of her children are employed at the factories, earning an income of 3 USD each per day to help cover the family’s expenses. S. has to spend 66 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity and water supplies, and 60 USD on other necessary expenses every month.  S. is requesting a loan of 400 USD to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Muralla

texts.en:
Muralla O. is a 47-year-old mother from Culasi, Antique, Philippines, a municipality where the mountains meet the sea. She is married to Romeo O., a 50-year-old farmer, and they are blessed with two children- Ramon Christopher, 21 years old, and Apple Jean, 16 years old.

Muralla is a very simple woman who has a simple dream in life and that is to see her children graduate from college so that they will get a better job someday.

Since 2005, she has never requested a loan more than 20,000 PHP because she always puts into consideration that she will only borrow the amount needed for her business in order to avoid mis-utilization of loans and to maintain her good performance as a member.

She has successfully paid her last loan and presently she is requesting a loan of 11,000 PHP. This amount will be utilized as additional capital for her pig-raising project. The income from this project really helps her to address the needs of her family, especially the educational expense of her children. 

She also wishes that someday, through her business and with the support of ASHI and its field partner, they will rise up from poverty.

loans.use: Hog fattening

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita L. is 51 years old from Bitadton, Culasi, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Hector L. Sr. and they are blessed with two children, both of them are still in school.

They earn a living through farming and hog fattening, which helps them sustain the needs of the family.

Margarita has been an active member of ASHI Antique North Branch since 2004. Being a member, she maintains 100% credit rating in repayments, attendance and project. She has also availed some incentive loans from ASHI such as house repair loans and educational loans.

For her next loan she is requesting 15,000 PHP to use as additional capital to her hog-fattening project.

Her greatest dream in life is that her eldest child, Hector, will finish college and by that, he also helps his younger sister, Hyniah, to pursue her dreams. In addition to that, Margarita is also dreaming that someday their standard of living will improve.

loans.use: Hog fattening

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S., 38, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo province. She is a professional silk weaver, typically making US$ 2 of profit every day. She has been doing this business since 2004, while her husband works at a farm, growing rice and vegetables. He usually makes US$ 1 per day. Three of the children are in school. Meas S. would like to take out a loan of US$ 700 to purchase more silk.

loans.use: To purchase more silk

loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en:
A very hardworking mother is Nerissa O. one of the active members of ASHI Antique North Branch. She is already 60 years old and a resident of Bitadton, Culasi, Philippines. She is married to a very supportive husband Gilberto O.. Through their courage and industry, one of their children finished  college and got a degree.

They earn income through her variety store and the income that they earn from this business has been a great help to cover their basic needs. Though the income from this business is unstable, she is really wise in using the capital entrusted to her by the Institution. 

At the age of 60, she is still strong and always inspired in doing her business. On the other hand; her business gives her an income and the same time pleasure.

She is dreaming that someday her youngest child Gilner will also finish her studies through college and in that way, she will find a decent job someday because she doesn't want their children and their grandchildren to experience the hardships brought on by poverty.

Presently she is applying for a loan amounting to Php.8,000 which will be used as additional capital for her variety store business.

loans.use: Variety Store

loans.name: Kuy

texts.en:
Kuy R., 54, is a widow and lives in Takeo province with four of her children. Since 2009, she has been making and selling cakes in the local market for a profit of US$ 3 per day. And two of her children are teachers at a state school. They earn US$ 1 each a day. 

Kuy R. wants to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to make a new investment. She will sell roast chickens and purchase a motorbike. (Kuy R. is pictured with her oldest daughter.)

loans.use: Sell roast chickens and purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mex

texts.en: Mex M., 55, is a widow living in Takeo province with her daughter. To earn a living, she has been selling cakes in the local market and is able to make about US$ 3 in profit each day. Her daughter is a hairdresser, typically making US$ 4 per day. Mex M. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase hair dressing tools for her daughter to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase hairdressing equipment for her daughter

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun S., 38, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She works in a grocery store, typically making US$ 3 in profit per day, while her husband is a taxi driver. On average, he earns US$ 5 per day. This couple has five children; four are in school and one is too young to attend school. 

Sun S. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to replace an old and unreliable car for her husband to continue his transportation business.

loans.use: To purchase a taxi for her husband

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine has been an ASHI member since 2001. Her family is very glad that she has an opportunity to improve their quality of living through the income of the farming business she has established with the support of the loans she has requested from ASHI. 

Her husband’s support of her farming business is Christine’s inspiration to continue going through the challenges of poverty while growing her business despite that. The farming business has brought pleasure to her family. Because of its profits, she has been able to support the family. Being a good mother, she always wanted to support her children in whatever career they would be taking to better their own personal life. 

Aside from her farming business financed by the loan she received from ASHI, she also sells  different small goods, which is her way of saving her profits to support the needs of her family, especially in the education of her children. With that, Christine is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to be able to purchase fertilizers, rice seeds “palay”, and support her second venture. This would make their business grow and make more profit, which will enable her to reach her ambition in life.

Her long-term goals are for her three children to complete college and find better employment in the future. Education is their priority. This is the only wealth she can leave to her children that others can’t steal. The couple’s looking forward to that soon changing their lives, which are currently in poverty.  Aside from aiming to get out of poverty, they are also dreaming of the best in life that lives together and happily forever. 

Christine is glad to be a Kiva borrower and grateful for Kiva offering loans to support her business efforts.

loans.use: purchase fertilizers, rice seeds "palay", and support her second venture

loans.name: Khem

texts.en: Khem C., 20, is a local teacher in Takeo province.  He is single and lives with his elderly mother and four brothers and sister. On average, he makes US$ 3 each day. His mother grows rice and makes US$ 1 per day. Khem C. is asking for a loan of US$ 900 to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en: Ouk O., 50, is a widow living in Takeo province with her seven children. She is a recycler, collecting plastics and canes since 2009. She typically makes US$ 3 per day. She is also supported by three of her children, working in a garment factory. Ouk O. is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work

loans.name: Bach

texts.en:
Bach C., 38, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a farmer, typically making US$ 1 per day, while her husband, pictured here, is a wedding chef and earn US$ 5 per day. This couple is also supported by two of their children, working in construction. 

Bach C. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase rice and resell it for a profit to help support her family.

loans.use: Sell rice

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 41 years old. Leo is married and has two children aged 10 and 7. To make a living, Leo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Leo has been farming for more than a few years now. He is hoping to increase his yield and have a better income.

Leo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leo is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 50 years old, married and has 2 children aged 22 and 16. Lucia owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lucia also raises pigs and chickens.

Lucia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds and other farm supplies

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 54 years old and has 2 school-aged children. She earns her living through farming. She plants rice crops and sells her harvest to the market. She also grows pigs for fattening and sale. Merlie is a hardworking mother. She wants to provide for all her family's needs.

Merlie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand it.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira A. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Canonoy, Brgy. Miranda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fishing business. Her husband, Teodoro A., 51 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 19 and 27 years old.

Elvira joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Elvira has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty with her hard work. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,000, which she intends to use to buy a new engine for a fishing boat. She plans to save up for future home repairs and business improvements. Elvira A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase a new engine and equipment

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 49 years old, married and has 6 school-aged children. She plants rice and raises pigs for a living. She spends most of her time tilling her rice farm. When she is free of farming duties, she raises her pigs. She is planning to get more piglets to raise and sell.

Nilda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nilda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies, piglets and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies, piglets and feed

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en:
Genoveva N., 41 years old, is married and supports her family by operating a farming (vegetables) business. She lives in Sitio Bayon, Brgy. Paticui, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Genoveva is now borrowing PHP 29,000 in order to fund the operations of her plantation. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Genoveva hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to fund the operations of her vegetable plantation

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina M. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Bulobito-on, Brgy. Miranda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Cesar M., who is 53 years old, works as a welder to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business. They have three children who are aged between 22 and 26 years old.
Georgina joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Georgina has been gradually lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 22,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing 24,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy stock for her general store so that she could continue to save up for future improvements to the business and savings for the future. Georgina M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Raya

texts.en:
Raya T. is a single mother of a ten-year-old girl. She was born into a large family of teachers and was always eager to study, but unfortunately, she couldn’t continue her studies because she needed to help her parents to earn a living. Raya started to sell garden stuff at the local market and opened a sales location there. In 1998, in order to find a better place to live, she moved to Belovodskoe village where she continued her business in sales. Raya decided to sell ware and detergents and, owing to her wide experience in this activity, achieved success. With the revenues, she was able to buy a flat which was reconstructed as a grocery store. She bought goods and resold them by herself, without any help. Her shop became known for the good quality of the products and attentive customer service.
Now Raya wants to take a loan of 60,000 KGS to broaden the assortment of goods in her shop. It will allow her to raise floating capital and increase her number of customers. Raya believes that her optimistic spirit and perseverance in her business will help her to improve her family’s lives.

About Bai-Tushum and Partners
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To broaden her assortment of goods

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy A. is a widow who lives in Sitio Ubay, Brgy. 1, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living selling fish and raising hogs. Judy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Judy has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy piglets to raise so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Judy A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital to buy fish to sell and piglets to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
Myra S. is from the village of Bangahan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 36 years old and married with four school-age children. To make a living, Myra has a store selling vegetables  such as squash, chayote, cabbage. She also repackages soy sauce and vinegars in cellophane containers to sell retail. Myra has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Myra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Myra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en:
Jovy A. is from the village of Brgy. Mauan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old. Jovy is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jovy owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Jovy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Jovy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jovy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Serapia

texts.en:
Serapia N. is from the village of Kimanait, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 54 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Serapia has s a business selling kitchen wares — casseroles, frying pans and rice cookers. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Serapia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and aa working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Serapia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita B. is from the village of Mohon, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old and married with four adult children. To make a living, Anita owns a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Anita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC and is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale. This will be the second loan taken out by Anita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food to sell

loans.name: Nub

texts.en: Nub S., 41, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia — an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. is a farmer earning an income of about USD 0.5 each a day. Her husband is a driver, earning an income of USD 1 a day. Two of her children are factory workers, earning an income of USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. S. has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 5 on electricity and water supplies, and USD 70 on other necessary expenses every month. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase fruit to sell in front of the factory in the city. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina T. is from the village of Sampagar, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Lina owns and operates a specialized retail store. Her main source of income comes primarily from selling daily use products such as lotion and shampoo in the local community. Lina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

Lina joined HSPFI in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lina is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Lina from HSPFI. Lina plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her services.


About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory use as working capital

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry A. is from the village of Brgy. Mauan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 50 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Henry owns and operates a business raising livestock. His main source of income comes from raising breeding pigs. Henry has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. 

Henry joined ASKI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 34,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Henry is requesting a loan of 40,000 PHP to purchase additional pigs to raise. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Henry from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his livestock business to improve and expand his business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase pigs to raise

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom M. is 52 and married with six children. She and her family live in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temple. Mom and her husband are farmers, earning a daily income of about 1 USD. Two of her children are employed by factories and each earns a daily income of 3 USD that goes to help cover family expenses. Every month, Mom has to spend 83 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity and water, and 50 USD on other necessary expenses. 

Mom is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase blacksmith supplies to improve one of her children’s businesses. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. In the future, Mom would like to use any profit to repair her house.

loans.use: to buy blacksmith supplies

loans.name: Thou

texts.en:
Thou S. is a 51-year-old widow who lives with her two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, in an area known for a pre-Angkorean temple. Thou raises cows and sells fish, earning a daily income of about 4 USD. Every month, Thou has to spend 50 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity and water, and 55 USD on other necessary expenses.

Thou is therefore requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase more fish to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. In the future, Thou will use her profit to repair her house.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
With working capital, Gloria’s sewing business will keep on growing and she will be able to offer improved services and be better able to meet the increasing demands of her regular customers. Through the support of the Kiva partner ASHI, Gloria hopes that her family will soon improve their quality of life and move forward out from poverty.
 
Gloria’s future goal is to have a tailoring shop that will allow her to employ others. She also wants to sustain a long-term stable business. Gloria is requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva for 18,000 PHP to purchase cotton fabric and maintain her sewing business. The loan will further Gloria’s dream for her children to have a decent way of life.

loans.use: to purchase cotton fabric and maintain sewing business.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov C. is 29, married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for the Pre-Angkorian Temple. C. sells vegetables, earning an income of about $3 a day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $2 a day. C. has to spend $60 on food, $5 on electricity and water supplies, and $45 on other necessary expenses every month.  C. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe L. is from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 61 years old, widowed, and has five adult children. To make a living, Fe owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling dried fish  including danggit, pinikas, and tamban, in the local community. Fe has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to to purchase additional dried fish to buy and sell. Fe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. This loan will be Fe's second loan  from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en:
Ouk P., 60, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. P. sells fruit and vegetables, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. One of her children is employed at a factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. P. has to spend USD 21 on food, USD 10 on electricity and water, and USD 10 on other necessary expenses every month. 

P. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to build a shop to sell groceries, vegetables, and fruit. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P. appears in the photograph while she is doing her housework.

loans.use: build a shop to sell groceries, vegetables, and fruits

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn T. is from the town of Palayan, Aloran. She is 33 years old. Evelyn is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya M. is a 41-year-old married woman and supports her family by operating one business venture: a fishing business.  She lives in Sitio Bulobito-on, Brgy. Miranda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Ligaya is now borrowing PHP 18,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment.   This will be her 20th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ligaya aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie B. is 35-years old, married and supports her family by operating a general store business.  She lives in Purok Renon, Brgy. 9, Isabela , Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. 

Margie is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she could continue to purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Margie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more supplies to sell

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda G. is fifty years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Malipayon, part of the municipality of Pangantucan, Bukidnon province in the Mindanao islands. Yolanda buys and sells ready-to-wear and used clothing to the local community. Yolanda has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan, her sixth from HSPFI, of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional clothing to buy and sell. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe K. has a family of three children ranging in age from seven to eleven years. He is a resident of Litein Town in Rift Valley, Kenya. Wycliffe does mixed farming, producing milk, tea and maize that he sells in the local market. He has been farming for over ten years and employs three farmhands on his farm.

Wycliffe plans to use his loan to purchase a motor vehicle for transport purposes. He believes his loan will improve his income level and give the family a better standard of living. He holds the opinion that insufficient capital is the main undoing of him and other businessmen and appeals to Juhudi Kilimo to enlighten more people about their loans.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn L. is 47 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Poblacion, a part of the municipality of Kadingilan, Bukidnon province on the Mindanao islands. Jocelyn operates a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she buys and sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, biscuits and snacks to the local community. Jocelyn has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan, her fourth from HSPFI, of 14,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong V., 38, lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional silk weaver, typically making 2 USD of profit a day. She has three children living at home to support. Her husband is working as a recycler collecting plastic, paper and cans. On average, he earns 3 USD each day. Vong V. needs a loan of 1100 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to attach to a recycle trailer.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for recycling activities

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: Jackson M. is forty eight years old and married. His wife is a nurse and they have two children aged sixteen years old and nine years old. They hope to give their children a good education to the university level. Jackson’s business is located in a busy commercial area in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. He owns a general store in which he sells such items as sugar, rice, bread, flour, cooking oil etc. He has been selling to the local people for the last 7 years. He says that this business is profitable, but he still has financial constraints which is his major challenge. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 15,000 KES to add stocks of sugar, rice, flour and cooking oil. He hopes to be a wholesaler in various shopping centers. He describes himself as ambitious, hard working and social.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of sugar, rice, flour, cooking oil

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita C. is from the village of Bangahan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Carmelita is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income comes primarily from making and selling Filipino snacks, delicacies like bitso-bitso and toron, in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Carmelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients and increase working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Carmelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Noun V., 36, sells vegetables in the local market in Takeo province. She is married and has six children. Living in Takeo province, she is able to make about 3 USD in profit a day. Her husband stays at home growing vegetables for his wife to sell at the market. The couple is also supported by two of their children who work in a garment factory.

Noun V. wants to take out a loan of 600 USD to reinvest in her vegetable business.

loans.use: To invest in her vegetable business

loans.name: Ramadhan

texts.en:
Ramadhan M. is a married man with two children, one who attends school while the other is still too young to do so. He rents a house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expense is his rent.

Ramadhan has operated a meat roasting business for over a year, selling his meat at retail to his neighbors and passersby. Ramadhan’s major business challenge is the high cost of transportation.

Ramadhan decided to join Yehu to get loans to modify his business. With 40,000 KES he wants to purchase furniture and fittings for his food stall. He hopes to own a butcher shop in the future.

loans.use: To purchase furniture and fittings for his food stall

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios B. is a married woman with five children who are between 22 to 31 years old. She lives in Barangay Tuguis, a part of Hinigaran municipality, Negros Occidental province on the Mindanao islands. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Francisco B., 55 years old, works as a guard and also helps with his wife's store.

Remedios joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past fifteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Remedios has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, lifting the family's standard of living.

For this, her sixteenth loan, she is borrowing 21,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for her general store so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs and savings. Remedios B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Norabel

texts.en:

To make a living, Norabel owns and operates a business making and selling food. Her main source of income comes primarily from making and selling snacks and other delicacies like halo-halo (crushed ice flavored with evaporated milk and a variety of sweet beans and fruit) in the local community. Norabel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. 

Norabel joined HSPFI in 2007 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase the raw ingredients she needed to make her products. Norabel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional raw ingredients and provide working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Norabel from HSPFI.She chose to remain in this loan as her 6th cycle. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Conrado

texts.en:
Conrado C. is from the town of Banga. He is 38 years old and married with four school-aged children. His eldest child is 16 and the youngest is only five. To make a living, Conrado owns and operates a business raising crops. His main source of income comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice. Conrado started farming at his parents’ farm when he was a teenager. He is thankful to have learned farming at an early age because he is now benefiting from the skills he has acquired over time.

Conrado joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase three sacks of fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Conrado from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to pay his children’s school tuition fees. 


About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Juliet also manages a sari-sari (general) store where she sells a variety of products. She works hard to help provide for the needs of her family and fund her children's education.

loans.name: Chinarkul

texts.en:
Chinarkul S. is a 53-year-old married farmer with three grown children. She started her business breeding livestock almost twenty years ago, which became the only means of subsistence for her family.  With the initial capital of 7,000 Kyrgyz Soms, she managed to raise her floating capital and, at present, she earns about 5,000 Kyrgyz Soms each month.  

To reduce expenses for the livestock's foraging, she pastures her livestock in mountainous areas with native grasses.  In order to increase the number of cattle, Chinarkul obtained two loans from Bai-Tushum and Partners and repaid them without any delays. Now Chinarkul is applying for a loan of 64,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy bull calves. With the revenues, she plans to broaden her business by means of breeding. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners, one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan, uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase bull calves

Mariluz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mariluz has been lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. One of her previous loans of 19,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, greatly improving the family’s standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, Mariluz is requesting a loan of 19,500 PHP to use as additional capital to buy more clothing to sell so that she can continue to save for future home repairs. Mariluz  J. is a Project Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward achieving her dreams.

texts.en: Mao N. is a 27 year old man who lives in Kompong Chhnang Province. To earn a living, Mao spends at least eight hours per day in the construction field. He normally earns an average of $2.50 per day to help cover his family’s daily living expenses. Mao has a life partner in his mother who operates a business in front of her home selling pots which are made from clay. Presently, Mao faces difficulty with transportation in that he always hires a taxi when he needs to go to work or anyplace else. To reduce the cost of transportation, he would like a $400 loan in order to buy a used motorbike for riding to work.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for riding to work.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza A. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 20 years old. Liza is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Liza owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling home made chorizzo or sausage in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month in this activity.

In 2010, Liza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Liza is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Liza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo R. is from the town of Banga. He is 46 years old. Leo is married and has 2 children aged 10 and 17. Leo's wife is a teacher, while he is a farmer. He works hard to give his family everything they need. He tills his own land where he plants and harvests rice crops. He says he is hoping for the weather to cooperate so he will have a better yield. He plans to buy his own farm equipment soon.

Leo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leo is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support his family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Lucille

texts.en:
Lucille A. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 59 years old. Lucille is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Lucille owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling homemade sausage or chorizzo in the local community. Lucille has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lucille joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucille is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lucille from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her ower's business.

loans.name: Ma. Jessica

texts.en: Ma. Jessica C. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, detergents, junk foods and biscuits, as well as electronic loads of several networks like Smart and Global in her community. She is a 34-year-old single woman from the village of Old Kibawe, Bukidnon. Ma. Jessica has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Ma. Jessica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Ma. Jessica is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. She is 33 years old, widowed and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. Chille has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Chille joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Chille is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. Rosemarie has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a single man who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is transportation.

He has operated a barber shop for over three months. His potential customers are neighbors and passersby. Charles faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. During week days, he experiences low customer turn out because of work inconveniences while, during the weekends, he experiences high customer turn out.   

He decided to join Yehu to get loans to change his business. With the Kshs 20,000 loan, he wants to purchase mirrors and a hair-cutting machine.

loans.use: To purchase mirrors and a hair-cutting machine.

loans.name: Suos

texts.en:
The young woman shown in the picture is Mrs. Suos S., 24 years old, who lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She is employed in a garment factory that is full of garment workers. She generates a profit approximately of US $3.00 a day to help pay for her family’s daily expenses with more stability. Her husband also works as garment worker and has a fixed salary per month. This couple has only one child who lives with them.

Mrs. Suos S. will be using her loan to buy some soil that will be used to raise the low part of her house, which is lower than street. This is loan will provide for her and family and help them to live a comfortable life.

loans.use: To buy soil to raise the low part of her house, which is lower than street.

loans.name: Tap

texts.en: Tap V. is 42 years old. He has a business making rice wine and raising pigs. He lives with his wife and four children in Takeo Province. On average, he makes US $3.00 per day while his wife sells grocery products, typically making US $1.00 each day. Three of their children are in school and one is a garment factory worker. Tap V. wants to take a loan of US $400 to raise more pigs.

loans.use: To raise pigs

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida M. is from the village of Poblacion in Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Aida is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Aida makes and sells household furniture, such as sofas and dining tables, to local businesses and community members. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Aida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be Aida's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina M. is thirty-six years old. She is married and they have four children between two and fourteen years old. Her business is located in Karunga in a very busy business market of Thika, the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. She sells clothes, including sweaters, blouses, skirts, shirts and even shoes.She has been in this business for four years and her target market is mainly women. She says that this business is profitable and her only major challenge is that the business is seasonal, so business is very slow in some months. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 10,000 to buy shoes to expand her business. In future, she hopes to give her children a high-quality education to the university level. She also hopes to open a big boutique. She describes herself as innovative, patient, social, creative and independent.

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell in her clothing store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena G. is from the village of Tupsan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old. Elena is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling ice cream bars in the local community. Elena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be Elena's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:
