loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Virgenia

texts.en:
Virgenia S. is 43 years old and married. She supports her family by operating two businesses: a carinderia (eatery) and a general store. She lives in Purok Moises, Barangay Camangcamang, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF -- Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her carinderia and general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8000.

Virgenia is now borrowing PHP 19,000 so that she can continue to fund her food production operations. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF -- Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within the repayment term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Virgenia aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operation of food products

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena L. is from the village of Barangay Mauan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years old. Elena is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Elena has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Elena is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be Elena's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina R. is a married woman who lives in Barangay 2, Siaton, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business. Her husband, Alberto R., who is 50 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between seven and twelve years old. Felomina joined NWTF -- Project Dungganon in 1999, because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF -- Project Dungganon, Felomina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.

Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,500, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her eleventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for the business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Felomina R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operations of a fish selling business.

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe S. is from the town of Banga. She is 47 years old. Maria Fe is married and has three children, aged 24, 14 and 8. To make a living, Maria Fe owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Maria Fe wishes to have a better income to sustain her family's needs, especially her children's education.

Maria Fe joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizers. This loan will be Maria Fe's first loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies, such as fertilizers.

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo A. is from the village of Tangaro, Catarman, Camiguin Province. He is 58 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Danilo owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling Christmas lanterns and other home decor like wall frames in the local community. Danilo is just starting this business.

In 2010, Danilo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Danilo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Danilo is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional materials needed for the christmas lanterns & working capital. This loan will be Danilp's 3rd loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a married man with two children who attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

He operates a retail shop, selling sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and tea leaves for over three years. His potential customers are neighbors and food vendors. Julius faces a major challenge of high cost of transporting goods from the market place where he purchases them, to his shop for resale. He hopes to open a wholesale shop someday. 

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase stock of wheat flour and maize flour for sale at his retail shop. He decided to join Yehu to get loans and improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase stock of wheat flour and maize flour for sale at his retail shop.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann A. is from the town of Banga. She is 31 years old. Mary Ann is married and has a 14-year-old child. 
To make a living, she plants and harvests rice crop and vegetables. She sells her harvest to the market and it helps her provide for her family. Aside from the farm, she also grows pigs for fattening. She says it helps to have another source of income.

Mary Ann joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and feeds for the pigs. This loan will be the Mary Ann's first loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and feeds for the pigs

loans.name: Villa's Group

texts.en:
Villa F. is from the village of San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Villa is the leader for a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Villa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Villa prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Villa has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 2500 PHP each month.

Villa joined ASKI this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Villa is requesting her first loan, for 6000 PHP, to be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph N. is 27 years old. He is married with 2 children.  The oldest, who attends school, is 8 years old.  The younger child is 14 months old.

Joseph is a farmer from Nkubu town in central Kenya. He has been in the farming business for five years and sells products such as milk, maize, cabbage and tomatoes to middlemen. As another source of income, he works as a cobbler. 

Joseph has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry. In five years, he hopes to begin horticultural farming. The biggest challenges for his business have been low product prices as well as various pests and diseases. As a result of the loan, he hopes to be more productive and able to buy fertilizer and other types of farming inputs. He thanks Juhudi Kilimo for helping him to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Virginia

Virginia owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily traditional rice cakes known as bibingka, in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.
